newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thailand rejects finance firms plea on provisions.
newsitem.headline: Thailand rejects finance firms plea on provisions.

text.p: The Bank of Thailand turned down a request by finance firms to cut to 15 percent from 20 percent additional provisions for sub-standard assets, a senior central bank official said on Wednesday.

The extra provisions are required under a new central bank order issued last week. The finance firms had wanted the new provisioning requirement to be the same as the 15 percent set for commercial banks for sub-standard assets.

"The current provision rates -- 20 percent for finance firms and 15 percent for banks -- are appropriate. It reflects well the situation in the financial market," Thirachai Phuvanartnaranubala, director of financial institutions supervision and development, told Reuters.
"We have no plan to change the order the central bank issued last week, at the moment," he said.

The central bank, in a move to bolster a finance sector under growing threat from non-performing loans, ordered finance firms and commercial banks to set aside another 20 percent and 15 percent, respectively, in provisions for sub-standard assets, mostly linked to troubled property sector.
The provisions were on the top of existing reserves of 100 percent for doubtful debts.
Thirachai said commercial banks had so far built much higher reserves for troubled debts than finance firms and they also had better bargaining power and higher collateral.
Thirachai said the measure would be painful for finance firms in the short run but would benefit the whole sector in the longer term.
